metadata.description: Typography system specification for VUNO - AI Healthcare/Medical Imaging platform
metadata.rationale: VUNO's typography system balances scientific precision with modern aesthetics. Inter provides clean, geometric letterforms ideal for medical data visualization and dashboards, while Pretendard (Korean) maintains visual hierarchy and readability in bilingual contexts. The type scale (1.25 ratio) ensures clear hierarchy from UI labels to hero headlines, with fluid responsive scaling for optimal readability across devices.

heading.$description: Primary heading font - modern, geometric sans-serif optimized for medical dashboards and scientific content

body.$description: Body text font - excellent legibility at all sizes for long-form medical content and reports

monospace.$description: Monospace font for technical data, medical codes, and precise numerical values in dashboards

korean.$description: Korean-optimized font providing excellent readability for Hangul text with consistent x-height and weight distribution

korean-monospace.$description: Korean-compatible monospace for medical codes and numerical data in Korean interfaces

normal.$description: Regular weight for body text and standard content

medium.$description: Medium weight for subtle emphasis and UI components

semibold.$description: Semibold weight for subheadings and key UI labels

bold.$description: Bold weight for primary headings and critical alerts

xs.$description: Extra small - UI labels, captions, helper text

sm.$description: Small - secondary labels, table captions, annotations

base.$description: Base/body text - default size for all body content

xl.$description: Extra large - subsection titles, card headlines

scaleRatio.$description: Perfect Fifth ratio - mathematical scale for harmonious type hierarchy
scaleRatio.$rationale: 1.25 ratio provides clear visual distinction between sizes while maintaining proportional relationships, ideal for scientific and technical interfaces

tight.$description: Tight line height (20px at base) - single-line labels, dense data
tight.$accessibility: Use with caution - not recommended for body text over 2 lines

normal.$description: Normal line height (24px at base) - standard body text and readability
normal.$accessibility: Recommended for all body copy and standard paragraphs (WCAG AA compliant)

relaxed.$description: Relaxed line height (28px at base) - improved readability in medical reports
relaxed.$accessibility: Optimal for dense medical content and long-form documentation (WCAG AAA compliant)

loose.$description: Loose line height (32px at base) - maximum readability for print

tight.$description: Tight tracking (-0.32px at base) - headlines, display text

normal.$description: Normal tracking - default for all text sizes

wide.$description: Wide tracking (0.4px at base) - UI labels, all-caps text

extraWide.$description: Extra wide tracking (0.8px at base) - medical acronyms, emphasis

heading1.$description: Hero headline - brand statements and main page titles

heading2.$description: Major section heading - dashboard sections, report chapters

heading3.$description: Subsection heading - card titles, modal headers

heading4.$description: Minor heading - list items, component titles

heading5.$description: Small heading - metric labels, field names

heading6.$description: Micro heading - form labels, badge text

bodyLarge.$description: Large body text - featured content, introductions

body.$description: Standard body text - paragraphs, descriptions, medical content

bodySmall.$description: Small body text - secondary content, annotations

caption.$description: Caption text - image captions, helper text, UI labels

captionStrong.$description: Strong caption - emphasized labels, UI emphasis

code.$description: Code text - medical IDs, technical values, data fields

codeStrong.$description: Emphasized code - highlighted values, critical data

fluidType.$description: Fluid typography using CSS clamp() for smooth scaling across viewport sizes
$notes: min-size: smallest readable size on mobile
preferred-size: calculated as percentage of viewport width (0.5-3vw typical)
max-size: maximum size on large desktops
Smooth interpolation between breakpoints - no discrete size jumps
fluidType.$example: clamp(15px, 1vw, 16px) scales from 15px to 16px as viewport grows

scalingBehavior.$description: All typography scales responsively using clamp(). No media queries needed for type sizes.
scalingBehavior.$rationale: Ensures optimal readability across all devices without discrete jumps in size

pretendard.$description: Modern, variable Korean font optimized for on-screen readability
$pros: Superior rendering at small sizes (medical dashboards)
Variable font support for weight consistency

notoSansKorean.$description: Google's comprehensive Korean font with extensive character support

bilingualPairing.$strategy: Stack fonts with Korean first to ensure Hangul renders with proper font, Latin falls back to Inter

xHeight.$description: Pretendard has similar x-height to Inter for seamless mixing
xHeight.$benefit: Consistent visual weight in bilingual text

rendering.$description: Optimized hinting for on-screen display at 72-96 DPI
rendering.$benefit: Crisp Hangul rendering on medical displays

interHeadingBody.$description: Single-font strategy using Inter for all English content
$rationale: Geometric sans-serif conveys precision and science

pretendardKorean.$description: Korean-optimized pairing with consistent visual weight
$rationale: Pretendard designed for Korean medical/tech contexts
X-height matches Inter for seamless bilingual integration
Weight system perfectly aligned with Inter weights
$strengths: Excellent at small sizes (important for medical UIs)

monospacePairing.$description: Technical font pairing for medical codes and data
$rationale: IBM Plex Mono complements Inter (same designer philosophy)
Clear, distinct glyphs prevent medical code misreading (critical)
Noto Sans Mono provides Korean support in code contexts
$strengths: High legibility for numerical data (97.5°F readability)
Excellent for print and digital medical reports

designPrinciples: Geometric sans-serifs (Inter, Pretendard) convey scientific precision
Consistent weights build credibility and trust
High contrast supports accessibility and readability
Clear letterforms reduce cognitive load in medical contexts
Modern aesthetic signals innovation while maintaining professionalism
scientificTrust.$forHealthcare: Typography must be trustworthy and clear - poorly rendered medical information can have safety implications. Inter and Pretendard provide confidence through clarity.

bilingualConsistency.challenge: Korean and Latin scripts have different optical properties
$solution: Both fonts optimized for medical/technical content
bilingualConsistency.$result: Seamless visual hierarchy in bilingual medical dashboards

english.$description: English text with system fonts as fallback

bilingual.$description: Mixed Korean/English content - Pretendard renders Hangul, Inter renders Latin

monospace.recommended: 'IBM Plex Mono', 'Noto Sans Mono', 'Courier New', monospace

cssVariables.$usage: Apply via CSS custom properties for maintainability and theming

performanceOptimization.strategy: System fonts first (no HTTP request), with web font fallback
performanceOptimization.$rationale: Medical interfaces prioritize speed and reliability
$loadingStrategy: Use font-display: swap for graceful degradation

wcagAA.$requirement: Line height ≥ 1.5 for body text (24px at 16px base)
wcagAA.$compliance: All body compositions meet or exceed this

wcagAAA.$requirement: Line height ≥ 1.75 for body text (28px at 16px base)
wcagAAA.$recommendation: Use for dense medical reports and technical documentation

contrast.$description: Ensure sufficient contrast between text and background
contrast.$wcagAA: 4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text
contrast.$wcagAAA: 7:1 for normal text, 4.5:1 for large text
contrast.$context: Critical for medical interfaces where misreading could impact patient care

dyslexiaSupport.fontChoice: Inter includes excellent spacing and character differentiation
$recommendations: Use generous letter spacing for technical terms

mobileDyslexia.$note: Fluid type ensures readable sizes on all devices
mobileDyslexia.$minimum: Never scale below 14px for body text

body.$recommendation: Use line height 1.75 minimum for medical legibility

monospace.$description: Medical codes and technical data in print
monospace.$example: Patient IDs, test codes, lab values

printContrast.$recommendation: Always use 100% black text on white for medical documents
printContrast.$reason: Ensures legibility in archival conditions and photocopies
